TopicTitle: Estimating delta-v to orbit using gravitational force?

Articles.Content: I understand that I could just cheat and look at that map thing or check on the wiki, but I kind of want my probes to have a purpose. So using one of those science pieces to determine the gravitational force of a body, can I roughly estimate the amount of delta-v to get into a 25-50 km orbit?
if the body has no atmosphere I don't see why not, as long as you know the formula that is.

if the body has no atmosphere I don't see why not, as long as you know the formula that is.

Oh good. Would you happen to know a formula to use?

Not really sure but I think this could help:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocket_equation

The rocket equation is useful for calculating delta-V itself, but not necessarily for calculating the necessary delta-V to reach orbit. That requires you to know the gravity of the body and its actual physical size of that body (ie. its diameter). Unfortunately, I don't remember the exact equation involved, but that's a starting point, at least.
